page.title: 02CHANGES IN S.DOWNS LANDSCAPE
page.content: The traditional S.Downs landscape of short flower-dotted turf remained unchanged until the years following the l939-45 war. Grazing sheep kept rough grass in check, & chalkland flowers & beech woods flourished undisturbed. Modern farming methods have changed the face of the Downs. The turf has nearly all been ploughed up & planted with cereal crops & grass. The plough has brought to the surface quantities of flints & lumps of broken chalk. Some of the land is now managed grass- land, & Friesian bullocks & heifers graze in place of sheep. Conservationists are struggling to keep down scrub & coarse grass on the N. face & have succeeded in preserving many of the rarer orchids & other plants in some areas - e.g. Heyshott & Graffham Down Conservation areas.
